ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the basics of Korean language!
I learned how to write full sentences and learned helpful phrases and words.
I really loved the sense of community this class brought me. I developed great foundational knowledge of the Korean language and preliminary understandings of culture.
I learned how to speak, write and read Korean better as well as learn much more grammar than I had previously known. I also learned how to help fellow classmates.
I gained a basic understanding of korean sounds, pronunciation, grammar and vocabulary.
I developed basic Korean conversational skills and advancement in reading Hangul, the Korean alphabet.
Basic useful vocabulary, grammar, conversational skills in Korean.
Basic Korean speaking, reading, writing, and linguistic context.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some strengths of this course are that we followed a textbook and all classes/assignments followed a general schedule throughout the semester -- there was nothing too surprising!
This class is well organized and allows students to learn Korean in an engaging way.
I wish there was a little more emphasis on speaking
This class was very strong in its sense of rigor and understanding of beginner learners. I would say it could be a little slower, however.
Strengths: Collaborative classroom environment, encouraging atmosphere, teaching style from the professor, everything!

It presented phonological and grammatical rules in a progression that made a lot of sense. Our teacher was patient and helpful. 
Sometimes I wish we learned more informal ways of speaking so that it would be easier to understand everyday Korean speech, but I understand that it may make more sense to learn the more proper forms first.
I believe the course can be improved if the textbook correlated more with the curriculum. That or the textbook should only be used for its dialogues as lesson examples.

Strengths: loved the curriculum + variety of learning and testing methods, workload was very good (for the most part). Teaching and development of section camaraderie was excellent. Providing a more clear overview of all assignments in the syllabus and giving homework deadlines a little further in advance would be appreciated (e.g. oral presentations, especially those in groups).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The way the course is laid out made it very easy to grasp the course material. And I personally found it a very engaging and fun class!
If they want to learn Korean, this is a great introduction
Yes
I would. I would say everyone should gain an understanding of Hangeul beforehand.
I absolutely do! With more and more Korean media being introduced to Western audiences, I highly recommend exploring the language and culture Korea has to offer!
Yes! I improved my Korean skills to elementary from absolute zero and I had a lot of fun doing it.

I'd recommend this course to anybody interested in Korean culture. However, I will note that the majority of learning comes from the student's dedication to the language. Unless you actively practice with peers and/or consume Korean media throughout the semester, you won't have long-term usage of the language.
The general environment in my section was great, which made learning the content a lot of fun for everyone. With class everyday for the entire semester, our class became really close.
Yes! Korean department instructors are lovely, and this is by far the most accessible and least unnecessarily stress-inducing East Asian language at Yale.
